statement:
If $\displaystyle\frac{a_1}{b_1},\,\ldots,\,\frac{a_n}{b_n}$ are any
real fractions with positive denominators and
$$m \;:=\; \min\left\{\frac{a_1}{b_1},\,\ldots,\,\frac{a_n}{b_n}\right\}, \quad 
   M \;:=\; \max\left\{\frac{a_1}{b_1},\,\ldots,\,\frac{a_n}{b_n}\right\}$$
are of the fractions, then $$\begin{aligned}
m \;\leqq\; \frac{a_1\!+\!\ldots\!+\!a_n}{b_1\!+\!\ldots\!+\!b_n} \;\leqq\; M.\end{aligned}$$
The equality signs are valid if and only if all fractions are equal; in
this case one has
$$\frac{a_1}{b_1} \;=\; \ldots \;=\; \frac{a_n}{b_n} \;=\; \frac{a_1\!+\!\ldots+\!a_n}{b_1\!+\!\ldots\!+\!b_n}.$$
[*Proof.*]{} Set $\displaystyle q_1 := \frac{a_1}{b_1}$, …,
$\displaystyle q_n := \frac{a_n}{b_n}$. Then we have
$a_1\!+\!\ldots\!+\!a_n = b_1q_1\!+\!\ldots\!+\!b_nq_n$, which
apparently has the lower bound $(b_1\!+\cdots+\!b_n)m$ and the upper
bound $(b_1\!+\ldots+\!b_n)M$. Dividing the three last expressions by
the sum $b_1\!+\ldots+\!b_n$ yields the asserted double inequality (1).

**Remark.** Cf. also the mediant.
